    • Method Detail

      • createObstacleCorners

        public static java.util.Set createObstacleCorners​(java.util.Set<GIS_element> obstacles,
                                                  Game game)
        This method will get an arraylist of obstacles, and a Game, and then creates new gis_element_obj (corner position) of the obstacles, as long as the position is outside of any other obstacles. (no overlapping). it returns the set of these objects, and also sets the game corners to this set.

      • initGraph

        public static graph.Graph initGraph​(GIS_layer targets,
                                    Game game,
                                    Map map,
                                    double ht,
                                    double wd)
        This method will get a GIS_Layer of targets, Game, Map, and height and width of the window called. The method will create a new Graph, source vertex is player object. targets are all vertexes available in the graph. it will calculate all corners of obstacles and add them to the graph to make the graph connected. the method will check between each pair of vertexes if there is LOS (line of sight, if they can 'see' each other with no obstacles between). if there is LOS, it will calculate edge weight between these vertex and add it as an edge to the graph. The method returns the Graph as and UNDIRECTED CONNECTED GRAPH. note: Dijkstra's algorithm has not run on this graph yet.
        Parameters:
        targets - GIS_layer, all targets/vertex to be used in the graph. fruits+packmen inside ONE layer is SUPPORTED!
        game - the Game we will take Obstacles from, and initialize obstacle corner into.
        map - map to be used in conversions and to calculate the line-of-sight between edges.
        ht - height of the frame to be used to calculate the line-of-sight between edges.
        wd - width of the frame to be used to calculate the line-of-sight between edges.
        Returns:
        Graph, G, an undirected-connected-graph. dijkstra's algorithms hasn't run on this graph yet.

      • pathToTargetInclObstacles

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> pathToTargetInclObstacles​(graph.Graph g,
                                                                              java.lang.String source,
                                                                              java.lang.String target,
                                                                              boolean greedy)
        This method gets a Graph, source GIS_element, a given target GIS_element object and a boolean Greedy. it calculates and returns the shortest path (ArrayList of GIS_Elements to move on this order) to the given target while avoiding collision with obstacles. if greedy is selected (true) we remove the first element from the target list. otherwise, we add the target to the last index of path returned.

      • addSourceToGraph

        public static void addSourceToGraph​(graph.Graph g,
                                    Point3D sourcePos,
                                    java.lang.String nameSource,
                                    Game game,
                                    Map map,
                                    double ht,
                                    double wd)
        This method will get a graph G, a Point3D representing the source position to add to the graph, a name to be used for this vertex in the graph. Game, Map, height and width of the window called. it will also add all relevant edges for this vertex.
        Parameters:
        g - the Graph we want to add the vertex to.
        sourcePos - the Position in Point3D of the source vertex we want to add.
        nameSource - the name preferred to be used for the added vertex.
        game - the Game we will take Obstacles from, and initialize obstacle corner into.
        map - map to be used in conversions and to calculate the line-of-sight between edges.
        ht - height of the frame to be used to calculate the line-of-sight between edges.
        wd - width of the frame to be used to calculate the line-of-sight between edges.
